title: R and Python Coding Handbook for Undergraduate Statistic
text:
Welcome
Welcome to R Book for Undergraduate Statistic, this book contains code and study material for undergraduate students who major in statistics. I created this book to aid the student in their study. Based on my experience, undergraduate students tend to have a hard time coding and applying statistics, so I hope this book will ease the burden of students that are learning statistics.
In this book you will find material and code for undergraduate statistic class in. This book is based of the Institute Technology Sepuluh Nopember Curriculum and my Experience studying there. You will learn how to use r for statistical analysis for many difference class.

title: Introduction
text:
What will you learn
In this book you will learn how to code and applied statistical method for the following classes

text:
Intro to R
Intro to Statistic
Intro to Probability
Numerical Analysis
Regression Analysis

Sampling And Survey
Mathemathical Statistic

Nonparametric Analysis
Stochastic Process
Intro to Econometrics
Applied Multivariate Analysis
Categorical Analysis
Intro to Survival Analysis
Intro to Time Series Analysis
Statistical Quality Control
Data Mining And Vizualization
Simulation Techniques
Statistical Machine Learning
Data Analysis
Intro to Spatial Statistic
Computational Bayesian Analysis

title: Introduction
text:
Prerequisetes
You are assumed enrolling in a statistics major or some equivalent. You are also assumed to have access to a laptop and computer with R and R Studio installed. If not here is the following link to install them. Also, you are assumed to be numerically literate.

title: Introduction
text:
What you won’t learn
This book will not go in depth on theory and math. Focusing more on their application instead.

title: Introduction
text:
About me
Hi i’m Aufar, if you like this book feel free to say “Hi!” on LinkedIn
Also if you find any error in this book feel free to contact me using my email aufarromeo@gmail.com

title: Introduction
text: Acknowledgments

title: Intro to R
text:
In this part of book we will learn the basic of using R. If you already proficient with R you can skip this part of book and continue to other parts. In this part we will learn the following subject.

Data Operation
Data Manipulation
Data Import
Conditional Statement
Loop
Fucntion

Also there is other resource to help you learn R, ff you never use R, Hands on Programming with R is a good book to start. To download R you can go to CRAN (comprehensive R archive network) https://cloud.r-project.org. If you also have not download RStudio, you can download it from https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/, Rstudio itself is an integrated development environment, or IDE for progamming with R. Other book that i reccomended is R for Data Scienece 2nd Edition, this book will teach you many other R skill.

title: 1  Data Operation
text:
1.1 Basic Data Type
There is 4 basic datatype in R which is:
Integer is data that has form of whole number like -10, 10, and 0. Numeric or float is numerical data that hasi decimal like -1.5, 2,6 and etc. Character or string is data type that store text like apple, fruit, etc. it is created by using quotation mark “” like this “apple”. Logical or Boolean data type that only has two possible value which is TRUE and FALSE. Here is an example for creating each data type:
# <- operator is used to assign value to variable
# Note: R is case sensitive so be careful when naming variable and assigning them value

# Integer
a <- 1L
## L is for whole number, we could write othe like 3L, 4L and so on

# Numeric
b <- 2.5 

# Character
c <- "stat" 

# Logical
d <- TRUE 
## Other Boolean Value is False, we could also shorthen them using T and F for True and false

# Note: Use class() to Check data type
The code above means we create variable and assign them specific value using <- operator. Here is the result of class for each variable we created
Data Type of a: integer
Data Type of b: numeric
Data Type of c: character
Data Type of d: logical
We could see for each variable has the correct data type that we has assign.

title: 1  Data Operation
text:
Integer
Numeric or Float
Character or String
Logical or Boolean

title: 1  Data Operation
text:
1.2 Basic Operation
Basic Operation which is



Operation
Symbol
Example




Addition
+
x+y


Subtraction
-
x-y


Multiplication
*
x*y


Division
/
x/y


Exponent
^
x^y


Modulus
%%
x%%y



Here is an example for each basic operation

# Define variable
a <- 10
b <- 3
c <- 2
# Addition 10+3 = 13
a+b

[1] 13

# Subtraction 10-3 = 7
a-b

[1] 7

# Multiplication 10*3 = 30
a*b

[1] 30

# Division 10/2 = 5
a/c

[1] 5

# Exponent 10^2 = 100
a^c

[1] 100

# Modulus 10%%2 = 0
a %% c

[1] 0

title: 1  Data Operation
text:
1.3 Vector
Vector is a collection of item that has the same data type or we could say it as one dimensional array. Vector in r can be created using c, here is an example

# Creating vector
x <- c(1,2,3,4,5)
x

[1] 1 2 3 4 5


we could see the output is

title: 1  Data Operation
text:
1.4 Array

# Create an array
arr <- array(1:12, dim = c(3, 4))
# Print the array
arr

     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
[1,]    1    4    7   10
[2,]    2    5    8   11
[3,]    3    6    9   12

# Access an element in the array
arr[2, 3]

[1] 8

title: 1  Data Operation
text:
1.5 Matrix

# Create a matrix
mat <- matrix(1:9, nrow = 3, ncol = 3)
# Print the matrix
mat

     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]    1    4    7
[2,]    2    5    8
[3,]    3    6    9

# Access an element in the matrix
mat[2, 3]

[1] 8

title: 1  Data Operation
text:
1.6 Dataframe

# Create a dataframe
df <- data.frame(
  Name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"),
  Age = c(25, 30, 35),
  Score = c(85, 90, 95)
)
# Print the dataframe
df

     Name Age Score
1   Alice  25    85
2     Bob  30    90
3 Charlie  35    95

# Access a column in the dataframe
df$Name

[1] "Alice"   "Bob"     "Charlie"

# Access a specific element
df[2, "Score"]

[1] 90

title: 1  Data Operation
text:
1.7 List

# Create a list
lst <- list(
  Name = "Alice",
  Age = 25,
  Scores = c(85, 90, 95)
)
# Print the list
lst

$Name
[1] "Alice"

$Age
[1] 25

$Scores
[1] 85 90 95

# Access an element in the list
lst$Scores

[1] 85 90 95
